sub_title: Recent Graduate - MSc Water Science & Management, UU
summary:
I am a recent graduate from the master's programme Water Science and Management, Utrecht University.
I conducted my master's thesis as an internship with KWR Water Research Institute. My thesis focused on estimating acceptable concentration levels for opportunistic pathogens in the Dutch drinking water supply through the implementation of a stochastic QMRA, for which I was awarded a grade of 8.41. I am now eager to apply the skills and knowledge I have gained through my studies and internship in a professional setting and am actively seeking a job in the Netherlands in the field of water and the environment, (particularly in the area of environment and human health).

projects.title: Estimating acceptable concentration levels of opportunistic pathogens in Dutch drinking water
projects.description:
-Worked on this topic for my master's thesis in collaboration with KWR Water Research Institute and Utrecht University, and was awarded a grade of 8.5 for my thesis report.

-The estimated concentration levels were determined for the pathogens Legionella pneumophila, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Aspergillus fumigatus, and Mycobacterium kansasii, through the implementation of a stochastic QMRA.

contributors.headline: Recent Graduate - MSc Water Science & Management, UU

projects.title: Investigating the Sustainability Ambitions of Dutch Water Boards
projects.description:
-Joint group research project with students from multidisciplinary backgrounds and KWR Water Research Institute, on the topic of investigating the sustainability ambitions of the Dutch water boards. 

-Specifically relating to the shifting role of water boards as a contributor to the national energy transition and circular economy, where wastewater is seen as a useful resource containing a high level of raw materials and energy recovery.

contributors.headline: Recent Graduate - MSc Water Science & Management, UU

projects.title: Human Health Risk Assessment on Lead Contamination from Mine Waste at Silvermines, County Tipperary, Ireland
projects.description:
-Conducted a comprehensive human health risk assessment as part of the final year thesis for my BSc in Environmental Science at University College Cork, Ireland.

-Utilised secondary monitoring data to investigate if the presence of lead and other heavy metals in Silvermines was causing health issues among community members.

-Applied the findings of the human health risk assessment to inform decision-making processes and provide guidance for remediation efforts, ongoing monitoring initiatives, and public awareness campaigns.

contributors.headline: Recent Graduate - MSc Water Science & Management, UU

projects.title: Investigation of the Effectiveness of Bait-Use in a Camera Trap Study of Mammals in Pulau Tioman, Malaysia
projects.description:
-Conducted a 5-day field trip in the secondary rainforest of Pulau Tioman as part of a 5-week summer programme at the National University of Singapore (NUS).

-Collaborated with a project team consisting of 7 students and 2 teaching assistants.

-Set out to determine whether baited camera traps were more successful in attracting mammals compared to non-baited camera traps, aiming to address contradictory findings in existing literature.

contributors.headline: Recent Graduate - MSc Water Science & Management, UU

profile_positions.description:
-Conducted my master's thesis on estimating the acceptable concentration levels of opportunistic pathogens for the Dutch drinking water supply.

-Framework used was a stochastic Quantitative Microbial Risk Assessment (QMRA) to estimate acceptable concentration limits of Legionella pneumophila, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Aspergillus fumigatus, and Mycobacterium kansasii in drinking water that meet current infection risk and DALY health targets.

-Developed strong research, analytical, and problem-solving skills, while adhering to strict quality standards and project deadlines. Received a grade of 8.5 for my written thesis.
profile_positions.title: Intern-Microbiological Water Quality & Health

profile_positions.description:
-Played a pivotal role as part of the UU Welcome Week team, responsible for organising the orientation programme for international students at Utrecht University.

-Oversaw and managed the logistical aspects of the week, ensuring smooth operations and a positive experience for participants.

-Successfully acquired external sponsorships for the event, demonstrating strong negotiation and persuasive skills.

-Effectively communicated with incoming students by promptly responding to emails, addressing queries, and providing necessary information.

-Collaborated closely with team members, demonstrating excellent teamwork and coordination abilities in a fast-paced environment.
profile_positions.title: Logistics Assistant (International Orientation Week UU)

company.name: Trinity Leisure Club, Abbey Court Hotel

profile_positions.company: Trinity Leisure Club, Abbey Court Hotel
profile_positions.description:
Lifeguard:

-Demonstrated a strong commitment to public safety by effectively monitoring and managing the swimming pool area, ensuring the well-being of all patrons.

-Conducted regular water sampling every three hours to uphold chemical and public health standards, ensuring the highest level of safety and cleanliness.

-Assumed additional responsibilities, including cleaning duties and managing the reception desk for membership sales, renewals, and swim accessory transactions.

Swim Instructor:

-Instructed children of various skill levels in both private and group lessons, fostering a positive and inclusive learning environment. Relayed feedback to parents/guardians about progress of child, as well as creating detailed lesson plans.
profile_positions.title: Lifeguard and Swim-Instructor

profile_positions.description: Summer job as a lifeguard for an outdoor swimming pool at Ballina, County Tipperary. Duties involved ensuring the safety of the public, opening and closing the pool on time, taking the entrance fee and addressing queries, and cleaning the pool and changing rooms in the evenings.
profile_positions.title: Lifeguard

volunteer_experiences.description: Villa Vrede is a community and activity centre for undocumented migrants in Utrecht. As a hostess, I welcome and chat with visitors and help with household chores such as food preparation, laundry and cleaning.

-Served as a dedicated orientation leader for Spring orientation at Utrecht University, playing a crucial role in welcoming and guiding new international students.

-Provided comprehensive assistance by offering city tours and sharing valuable insights about the city of Utrecht, helping students familiarise themselves with their new surroundings.

-Served as a reliable source of information, addressing questions and concerns from incoming students and offering practical tips based on my personal experience as an international student at Utrecht University.

-Demonstrated excellent interpersonal and communication skills, creating a welcoming and inclusive environment for students from diverse backgrounds.

volunteer_experiences.role: Co-Promotions Representative for Peer Support Steering Committee
volunteer_experiences.description:
-Served as a Co-Promotions Representative within a 12-member steering committee responsible for overseeing the Peer Support programme.

-Acted as a liaison between the committee and over 300 volunteer Peer Support Leaders (1st year mentors), advocating for their views and providing input on the programme's operation and structure.

-Participated in fortnightly committee meetings, contributing insights and feedback to improve the effectiveness of the programme.

-Collaborated with my co-rep to manage the free tea/coffee stand on campus, fostering a welcoming environment and providing a space for students to connect and seek support.

-Organised and implemented various campaigns aimed at promoting the Peer Support programme and attracting new recruits for the following year.

-Served as a Peer Support Leader, providing personal, practical, and social support to first-year students in my bachelor's programme at UCC.

-Played a vital role during orientation by leading a linked group of students, conducting campus tours, designing and facilitating icebreakers, guiding them to registration and organised talks, and addressing any questions or concerns they had.

-Engaged with students and visitors to the UCC campus through PITstop, a free tea and coffee stand run by Peer Support. Maintained smooth operations at the stand while connecting with fellow Peer Support Leaders and engaging in conversations with a diverse range of individuals.

-Contributed to the recruitment drive for the next cohort of Peer Support Leaders by distributing flyers on campus, participating in social media campaigns, and co-conducting interviews with a fellow Peer Support Leader.

-Played a significant role in the selection process, ensuring the recruitment of dedicated and passionate individuals to continue the Peer Support programme's success.

-Served as the Events Officer for the UCC Geological Society, taking an active role in planning and organising a variety of society events.

-Generated creative ideas for events, including inviting and coordinating guest speakers from both UCC and external institutions across Ireland and abroad.

-Liaised with potential speakers, arranging their participation and ensuring smooth communication leading up to the events.

-Took responsibility for securing suitable venues on the UCC campus, ensuring rooms were booked in advance or setting up online forums when necessary for virtual events.

-Maintained an updated UCC Societies calendar, ensuring that the Geological Society's events were listed, allowing for maximum visibility and participation.

-Collaborated with other society members to organize occasional social events, fostering a sense of community within the Geological Society.

-Volunteered as a writer for The University Express, the student newspaper of UCC, contributing articles to both the features and opinions sections.

-Focused primarily on environmental issues, using an informal, engaging, and humorous writing style to make these topics accessible to the wider student population.

-Covered a range of environmental topics, including marine microplastics, climate change, water usage, and Singapore as a biophilic city, aiming to raise awareness and promote sustainability among readers.

-Co-wrote a mini-series on animal biodiversity with co-writer Daragh Brown, who provided scientific animal facts. Integrated the facts into witty articles that communicated the importance of biodiversity and sustainability to a broader student audience.

-Demonstrated the ability to research, synthesise information, and present it in an engaging and accessible manner.
